Linearly dependent and independent
$u_1, \dots, u_m \in \mathbb{R}^n$

Consider a linear combination
$x_1u_1 + \dots + x_mu_m = 0$ which is equivalent to

$\matrixstart u_1 & \dots & u_m \matrixend \matrixstart x_1 \\ \vdots \\ x_m \matrixend = \bar{0}$

If there is a non-zero solution for $x_{1 \dots m}$, they are linearly dependent ($\iff Ax = 0$ for $x \neq \bar{0}$)

If there is $Ax = 0, x = \bar{0}$, they are linearly independent.

Let's take $A = \matrixstart v_1 & v_2 & v_3 & v_4 \matrixend$ and row-reduce it to e.g.

$B = \matrixstart 1 & 0 & 1 & 0 \\ 0 & 1 & 2 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & 0 & 1 \matrixend$.

Then $Ax = 0 \iff Bx = 0$
Working with $B$ is easier.
Pick your free variable to be non-zero (e.g., $1$), then inspect it to identify the dependence of some vectors on others.

You can pull out a vector $u_i$ for each free variable $t_i$ (by letting it $= 1$ and others $= 0$). Then the all solutions $x$ are $span(u_1, u_2, u_3, u_4)$
